I think the main source of the weight-loss claims is the fact that Keto is burning fat directly, rather than using liver stores.

Basically imagine your car has a 1 gal tank with a pump, and a 20 gal tank with a tiny tube. You might use half the tiny tank on a daily drive, and then you either top it off, or let the 20gal tank trickle through until you can get to a gas station. So you hardly ever touch the reserve, and refill it immediately anyway.

If you were to fast or go keto, you're emptying out that small tank completely and the pump starts pulling directly from the 20 gal tank. Now you can drive for ages without refilling, and it's emptying that 20-gal tank directly.

Same basic idea. Your liver stores glucose so you can go about your daily business specifically without losing weight. Your body is trying to avoid losing weight. If you empty the reserves, you're able to tap into the large reservoir that is your fat.

Pretty accurate video. Just one thing, you mentioned that with a Keto diet the lack of carbs means your body is not storing glucose, so you lose that weight and the associated water that binds with it. Whilst this is true, it is also true if you have carbs in your diet. Any diet for weight loss requires a calorie deficit over time and your body is not storing glycogen when you are in a calorie deficit. Obviously with any diet you go into a calorie surplus when you eat and then back into a deficit between meals, depending on meal timings, etc., but once you have been in an overall deficit for a while, all of your glycogen is used up and, whilst a small amount will get replaced when you eat, once you return to a calorie deficit it will get used up straight away. This is why most people experience rapid weight loss when they first start a diet, because of the depletion of glycogen and the associated water that binds to it, regardless of type of diet. On average this accounts for 0.5kg of glycogen and 2kg of water, which is roughly equivalent to 2500kcals of stored energy.

That 2500kcals of stored energy in the form of glycogen is the reason that training your body to use fat as fuel is really effective for endurance athletes, because they will frequently burn more than 2500kcals in an event and, whilst they can take on carbs during the event, even slower releasing carbs create somewhat of an unstable energy availability, due to the peaks and troughs of blood glucose levels created by consumption and insulin response. Fat cells on the other hand, although taking longer for the body to access the energy are limited only by a person's body fat percentage and, even a very lean athlete will have tens of thousands kcals stored. As the body gets used to using fat as fuel, it becomes more efficient at it, but it is still slower than using glucose, which is why it's not good for bursts of energy, but for endurance it's more than fast enough.

My theory is that the ketogenic state is an evolutionary byproduct. Humans have been around for 150,000 years, and we didn't have agriculture for over 95% of that time. So humans evolved for the most part without eating grains regularly. We ate a LOT of animals, a lot of fat as well. So I think the keto state evolved for those desperate times when we were hunting mammoths or running away from sabertooth lions or whatever. Basically, you couldn't be stopping to fill up on carbs every hour and you had to be mentally clear. The humans who could do this survived and produced more offspring, leading to their descendants making up the vast majority of the human population today.

Unfortunately this video makes some false claims in itself.
A majority of studies on diets use improper methodology. You have to separate out the ones that were designed to intentionally make diet X or Y look bad.
A majority of properly controlled dietary studies show carbohydrate restricted diets are superior to every approach for weight loss.
In order to believe otherwise, you would have had to either cherry picked studies or don't understand methodology.

Also, keto doesn't really give a physical performance edge in all categories. Arggh. Another issue with your video about "stored water weight." What you fail to understand is that it takes a lot of water to "turn" glucose to fatty acids, which are then stored in the lipid droplet of fat cells. This water is no longer water, but part of fat. When you are in ketosis and use the stored fat, the water is a waste product. This is a GOOD thing because it WAS fat. Also, high insulin promotes sodium retention in the kidneys (which is not a good thing) so on a ketogenic diet you could lose water through urination. This is easily solved by slightly increasing your salt intake. Eat a pickle or two and you are good to go.

C'mon, get your facts straight. Yes, Atkins is high fat/high protein. Keto, or Low Carb/High Fat actually wants to keep protein reasonable - about 20/30% of caloric intake. Why? Because protein can be turned into glucose through neoglucogenesis, which will raise insulin. Since ketones are not produced in the presence of insulin (and therefore elevated glucose), a high protein diet is not ketogenic. Atkins is certainly closer to Keto than the Standard American Diet or even Med diet, but it misses the larger idea of keto altogether.

Keto is becoming prominent not because of"bros" in the gym but rather because of the mounting evidence of it's efficacy. Also, it is not anti-carb, doesn't have a "yo-yo" effect, and is a completely natural state of being. The main focus of a Low Carb/High Fat diet is to keep insulin at it's proper level - i.e. low most of the time - which leads to greater insulin sensitivity and the production of ketones from stored fat. When practiced effectively (which is relatively easy once you get the hang of it), Ketosis quickly makes the obese return to normal weight, reverses insulin resistance, reduces inflammation, and can actually reverse type 2 diabetes in many people (by which I mean they can go off medication.) Also, evidence exists that ketones are actually preferred by the heart and brain. Calling the ketogenic diet a "bro" diet is insulting considering that it is the only diet that follows actual scientific study. All in all not a bad video - it would be better if you just tone down the innuendo.

NOTE: it's been quite difficult to measure myself, as on Keto I'm drinking ~3L/day (and when hiking 5.5~6.5L/day! So if you do so on Keto make sure you have enough water!), and also the irregularity in bowel movement can mask the progress for a week at a time.
So if you're measuring yourself frequently (as I do), just ignore when the scales show numbers above the last minimum weight you measured. In about a week I usually find a day to be able to measure my so called "dry" weight, and see the new minimum.

I mean yeah it's great for weight loss if that's your only goal and you do stick to it. It was prescribed to epilepsy patients because the ketones produced by the body for whatever reason helped with epilepsy, and they noticed weight just falling off patients. Eventually someone realized how much money could be made off of that. To so many people, the fact that it's so good at making you lose weight means it must be healthy, because that's all they think health is. But the fact that it's so good at it is what makes it unhealthy. Rapid weight loss is in and of itself destructive, not just the methods people use to get there. It's not only bad to lose weight extremely fast if you're starving yourself, the weight loss itself can harm you. Your body needs stability. Fat is basically an organ, it's not only for storing energy, it also acts as a buffer for the endocrine system, and is important to the immune system. A number of studies have even shown that people with higher amounts of body fat, while faring worse in some ways, actually get benefits as well (even scientists which go into studies with the idea that being on the heavy side is always bad, consistently find evidence that fat people do well in terms of mortality rates and show that health has far more to do with lifestyle and nutrition than weight. Many of scientists have found this research unacceptable under current norms but have been unable to dismantle it try as they might). Basically cutting out half of one of your organs in a couple months and just leaving the rest of your body to adjust without even so much as a recovery period is never good. There's a reason why our bodies only metabolize ketones when absolutely necessary. We were never meant to live off of them.

What this teaches us is that humans can survive on anything. We can adapt to anything. We're opportunate omnivores. But we weren't meant to just survive. You can get your nutrients from a variety of sources and put restrictions on where you get your food, and as long as you make sure you get decent nutritional balance, and compensate when needed, you'll do great. But when you start putting restrictions on what kinds of nutrients you're allowed to eat, as most fad diets do, very few people can come out of that healthy, unless you actually have generations upon generations of ancestors adapting to eating that way, as the inuit do. It's why 80+ percent of people who diet gain the weigh back, and just end up trying to lose it their whole lives, and most people who do have success in losing weight used to be thin anyway rather than being people who were fat their whole lives. People have made one single oversimplified facet of health into their entire goal and will strain their body and psyche to convince themselves they've achieved it. Intuitive eating, trusting our bodies to provide us with the proper instincts as it has for millions of years, is for the vast majority of people, the best thing they can do for themselves (barring certain preexisting physical or mental health conditions). But our culture has such a moralizing view of food and nutrients that that's inconceivable to most people. Don't torture yourself.

I've worked at a bookstore that sold diet books. I watched as keto books took over and the customers who live off of diet books seemed to become more and more self-hating in how they spoke of themselves in the checkout line, and became more and more obsessive about everything they buy and eat having to align perfectly with what these books say they need to do. And in this trend, sales of diet books went up. I've seen plenty of people and even a couple of researchers (by no means a majority) claim it gets easy after a few weeks but I look at their behavior, I look at how they speak about themselves, I look at their spending habits, and I look at how they have to forcedly laugh off offers of even a single cookie as if they're in a hostage situation because metabolizing glucose could ruin their streak, I just don't see it. It's obsessive, and it's not truly about health. It's barely even about weight loss, though that's the lie people have been trained to chase after to keep this going. It's really just all about money. If it was about anything else the narrative wouldn't be constantly switching back and forth. It was low-carb, then it was low-fat, now it's high-fat no-carbs, and now I'm seeing the industry start to switch back to claiming fats are evil, fearmongering and calling olive oil deadly. There's no stability. Because if there was stability, people could stick to something long enough to realize it never actually was going to work for them. Fasting is voluntarily not eating for a period of time during which you survive off of your fat stores.


Starvation is generally involuntary and describes the state in which your fat stores have been depleted and your body starts to consume its own muscles and organs.


The first is a good way to lose weight. The later is a not-so-good way to die.

This is not just an Inuit diet - prior to farming going all the way back to homo erectus, our ancestors got their nutrition mainly from meat, with fruits (sugars) and carbs (seeds) only for short seasons when these were available (they didn't store these and eat these year long like we do now nor in such quantities). The meat they got by two means - by running down prey in hot weather on the African plains (difficult), and by chasing away predators from their kills (easy and the preferred method). The nutrition they got from chasing away predators from their kills had a very high fat content because by the time they got there, the predators would have eaten a lot of the meat. Our ancestors could break the bones apart with stone tools to get at the bone marrow and brain - which are mostly fat. So the keto diet was our normal diet going back at least 2 million years and only changed 5000 years ago. The body's glucose burning mode which switches in when you eat more than 20 grammes of carbohydrates a day is an equally old adaptation to make use of fruits and seeds available during short fruiting and seed production seasons to fatten up. When these are available, your body instructs you to pig out on these, and the normal controls in a ketosis state against overeating when you eat too much are suspended.
It should be noted that a high protein diet isn't the keto diet. The keto diet is a high fat, moderate protein, very low card diet, as the Inuit eat. This is important because the energy that people would get from carbs, needs to be replaced by energy from fats if carbs are removed, so fat is important

Also the carb insulin hypothesis is just that, a hypothesis. There's a reason it's a hypothesis despite all of the public "in my experience" statements. It's likely a placebo effect, and the weight loss experienced is because it gives you a simple goal and makes label reading more attractive, and either calorie counting for people prone to overeating, and or the removal of pressure in regards of when to stop eating.

This is a great concise video on some of the history of ketogenic diets. However, the interesting thing again, is this idea that weight loss cannot be maintained on a keto diet. This is actually not the case, and there are many studies on that as well. Further, studies that have compared diets have quite a bit of methodological flawas. They also show comparative results in the weight loss department - but don't all discuss the improvements in metabolic markers in the end. A glaring methodolocical flaw, is comparing weight loss and control, without maintaining strict/ correct parameters for "keto" through the duration of the study.


An example of looking at weight control under the hood, is the ketogenic diet's impact on hunger related to physiological changes in circulating leptin and ghrelin hormomes. These greatly stabilize on a ketogenic diet - essentially, leaving you more satisfied and not craving. The other thing that is not discussed in this video, is the improvement in many other metabolic factors that are also related to weight loss and control, such as - hsCRP levels, insulin, blood glucose and HbA1c, waist circumference, blood pressure, reductions in triglycerides, and increased HDL levels. LDL in some people increase but usually they are the larger particles, as opposed to the small dense artherogenic particles involved with cardiovascular diseases. All these things matter in weight loss and maintenance and they work behind the scenes. for example--- how can you maintain a positive desire for weight loss if your MD tells you after 1year, that your blood pressure is high, and hbA1c level is prediabetic? the ketogenic diet is very well known for reducing both those issues! And as such - most people are motivated to continue with their weight maintenance journey.


The most compelling thing is about motivation. Many many studies on this have shown that people just more motivated to do something about their weight when they see results. That is one of the quickest things the keto diet will do due to the initial water losses - but this does not mean its only water. No, biochemically, fats will also be burned and yes you will lose adipose tissue. So ultimately - seeing the results is quite motivating and enough for most people to keep doing it. No other diet can really do that as functionally well as this one and continue to maintain good blood markers.


Further, once adapted to this way of utilizing ketones and glucose dynamically in the body, human physiology is primed for fuel partitioning as per food availability. With the decopuling to sugar and carb addiction - the human body can start to utilize proper food sources in an effective manner. So, yes you can transition to a lower carb diet of healthy carbs (whole plants, not garbage cookies and cakes), and you will still be able to maintain your weight. Again, the diet is controlled during the initial burn in to let the body adapt - after which some carbs can be added. This part has to be individualized as some people handle carbs differently from others as part of their genetic makeup.


Ultimately, though this is a good video - it omits some key components regarding the longevity of wt control compared to other diets. Yes weight loss can be similar - but in terms of nutrient density of the ketogenic diet, and metabolic markers exclusive of weight control, the ketogenic diet tends to do better - -and who knows, longer trials may shown severe reductions in carb addiction via changes in brain chemistry.


All diets have to be monitored as they tend to affect people in unique ways. And yes, different diets can work for different people. However, overarchingly, this diet affects both brain chemistry and metabolism in many beneficial ways. And yes, glucose and its requirement for HIIT and short burst anaerobic activity, is absolutely essential. Fats are not utilized well for that. so Agreed - glucose has its place in those activities. But the issue with exogenous glucose (in the forms of sugar and its many iterations) is that its addictive properties have been vastly exploited by the food and drug industries - causing insidious changes in brain chemistry as well as subsequent metabolic derangements.


Exogenous glucose is fine - but how much can you handle before addiction sets in?

@4:50, where did the claim come from that ketones aren't your body's first choice for fuel? 'Babies are born in ketosis, and remain in it until weened' -Amber O'Hearn. 'If there are both ketones and glucose in your blood, the brain eats the ketones first' -Dr. Ben Bikman. It seems from those facts that you could justify the opposite claim: ketones are first choice, glucose is shoddy second. Why, then, do we burn through our glycogen stores first when fasting or exercising? There seem to be a lot of reasons for this ... glucose isn't an endocrine organ, like fat, and so we protect fat stores (we are a really fat species). Also, we can't store much glucose, so it's a burn it or lose it (convert it to fat) situation with carbs. It's not good to get too fat, and so burning glucose first doesn't mean it's a preferred fuel, but that it's just wise energy management.

Right from the get-go this video seems to confuse the ketogenic diet with a carnivore diet or a low carb diet in general. Eating too much protein (and not enough fat) will actually kick you out of ketosis, because your body can turn certain amino acids into glucose by gluconeogenesis. For your diet to be considered ketogenic, it's not enough to just consume little to no carbohydrates, the absolute majority of your caloric intake has to come from fats (preferrably healthy ones).

The reindeer example actually plays into this too, as reindeer meat is typically really lean, i.e. low in fat. Only consuming extremely lean meat can lead to a form of malnutrition called rabbit starvation with symptoms like diarrhea, headaches, fatigue, low blood pressure and general malaise.

I for one suspect that glucose is the backup metabolism because for the vast majority of time that the Homo Genus existed our ancestors were primarily hunters. For the majority of the time, we were living in ketosis, either driving our metabolism on our own stored fat or eating animals we caught. The human digestive system can readily digest animal flesh and fat raw, while nuts and fruits were only sparingly available with most starches inedible before cooking. We've been omnivores with a carnivorous preference far longer than we've been eating agricultural starch. The glucose metabolism was just something we used to store energy, to fatten ourselves up so we could survive the times where there was no food available. Our genes never expected us to be able to get most of our calories from carbs

Did the Keto diet and going to get back on it again soon. I dropped 30 lbs in about a month and a half. It was tough to maintain though - not because I had a hard time staying on it (it’s my preferred method purely for fat loss, and find it easier because I don’t have to count calories, just avoid eating over 20-30g carbs a day) but because of how difficult it is to go out to dinners or eat at home with everyone else. I either had to order low carb veggies instead of potatoes, or eat at home and get a light meal. People got annoyed by my “healthy eating” telling me to “live a little” but the truth is you can’t overconsume carbs otherwise you’ll get knocked back out of ketosis (and feel like crap in the process - physically I mean).

Pretty much just ate eggs, a lot of feta cheese, Costco roast chicken (because you know.. it’s damn cheap and so good), and frozen broccoli and cauliflour). Drank almond milk protein shakes (that were made with stevia, almond milk because regular milk actually has surprisingly high amounts of sugar - and also found... almond milk makes protein shakes way easier to drink imo), heavy cream and MCT oil (easy to break down into ketones).

The thing is, it’s not a miracle. Combine the lack of carbs (which you only need about 20 of - for your average person - glucose is produced through other means as well, not just carbs) with high fat and moderate protein, you get full pretty quick. When I was counting my calories to see what I was taking in, It was between 1200-1400 calories a day - and I was not feeling hungry at all (since your insulin levels are stable - almost zero hunger pains, even when you are hungry, so it’s good to develop a routine.

You could do this with any diet that balanced your macronutrients though. I just found this the easiest one to maintain. I didn’t really need to think about what I needed to eat.

Did I rubber-band back? Very little, about 5-8 pounds (water weight usually due to depleted glycogen - carbs store about 4x their weight in water). Eating like this though taught me not to overeat, and even on carbs I’m okay with avoiding overindulgence... just like... keep me away from anything with the words hazelnut and chocolate in it.

Keto diets are also low protein diets. High meat diets are not ketogenic diets since proteins increase insulin levels. Carnivore diets generally require organ meats for vitamins and to not result in low baseline insulin levels by themselves. The association with insulin in many health issues including brain issues is insulin resistance and metabolic disorders. This is typically derived by long term ingestion of simple carbohydrates - not complex carbohydrates found in most fruits and vegetables. Thus a complex carb diet can produce similar affects to keto - but might also require intermittent fasting to suppress insulin. Intermittent fasting is found to be very helpful in all of these diets because it forces baseline insulin levels down for extended periods of time - at least 12 hours - and this can reduce health problems associated with metabolic disorders. Nothing is simple. There are many more details associated with calories, exorcise, physical training, vitamins, sleep, and so on. But each of these approaches can have their place if done right.

There's a huge difference between nuts and seeds and animal products.
Also, not all carbs are created equal. Most people mean refined, white flour or grains, and those are (except maybe 24-48 hours before any type of prolonged athletic competition, where you don't want a lot of pre-stool slowing you down) certainly not helpful in any diet regarding longterm health, also increasing the likelihood of CVD and Diabetes, also Non alcoholic fatty liver disease.
WHOLE GRAINS on the other hand are, along with any type of plant and legumes maybe the best addition to your diet you can make.
The 'best' diet is the one you can sustain for decades with no health repercussions. For most people, to go the hardcore health raw vegan way is not exactly sustainable in all situations in life. The Carnivore diet is not too different, with no longterm studies yet but with the knowledge of current trends (saturated fats and animal protein) it's unlikely to be the holy grail of nutrition science.
From whatever diet you want to transition from, it might be smart to incorporate subtle changes over time, to make sure you stick to it in the long run.
There's good evidence for a whole foods, plant-centered diet with a focus on minimally processed foods.

keto proponents advocate carbohydrate-insulin hypothesis based on the fact that insulin encourages fat formation and halts fat burning, which is true, but insulin control is not the real reason why the weight loss on keto occurs. it's simply a natural reaction of the body due to a total change of energy intake, with the energy flux shifting to fat instead of sugars meaning you burn more fat but you also STORE more fat, because it's now the currency for your energy trade.


keto can help people lose weight simply for the fact that eating fat makes them feel full faster AND longer, which on the long term helps create the ideal energy flux/deficit and is an especially powerful tool at that combined with intermittent fasting, which is easier to get into after a prolonged keto diet. excess sugars (especially fructose) are also stored as fat and short circuits your satiety hormone regulation, meaning it's easy to get a surplus in a sugar-based diet; takes more and more to feel full and faster hunger overtime (leading to insulin resistance, diabetes, etc..). the sleepiness/laziness from dropping blood glucose levels (which tends to stop you from being active) also doesn't help. ketogenic diet simply prevents this from happening, and you generally won't need to count calories because your body will simply tell you when to stop, trust me you won't be able to finish all them 50 strips of bacon you just fried.


lastly, it's a fact that your body absolutely NEEDS glucose at all times, and it will always be there available by itself, regulated by your liver through gluconeogenesis, the formation of glucose from other nutrients such as fat/protein. it doesn't really need your external help, otherwise we'd have gone extinct during the ice age.


trivia: the combination of fat and sugar literally hacks your reward system, they taste so good when combined it's like a drug. this is why kfc (deep fried batters) and ice cream (sweet milk fat) are a thing everywhere in the world. and of course, imo it's the absolute worst diet of all. just my two cents :)

The problem with the one-size-fits-all or even one-size-fits-every-seizure-patient mentality is that one size never fits all (as the video points out at the end). I started having seizures in high school (non-epileptic, though - caused by severe chronic pain). Oh, several of the dozens of doctors suggested cutting wheat (and/or carbs, though this was before Atkins) and eatting more meat. We soon realized that their stupid suggestions were making things drastically worse! The problem they never bothered to clue in on? I can't digest meat. After eating even small amounts of meat, my insides seize up in horrifically painful spasms that leave me writhing and screaming in agony for hours. Wheat is perfectly fine (in fact I pretty much live on wheat gluten, as the most body-friendly protien out there, at least for my body, which is also soy intolerant). Rice milk is much easier on my system than real milk, as well. (So much for the doctors' dumb "grain free" idea...) As for high fat, yeah, that too can trigger a seizure. My gall bladder stopped working in the 90s and they removed it (which only made things FAR worse, I might add), so my body can't process high fat foods (or here comes waves of horrid abdominal pain and seizures once again). To make matters even worse, without the use of sugar before meals, it is gut-wrenchingly painful to try to eat, and I cannot manage more than a few bites. (Even on the few occassions I've managed to do so, eating without sugar before the meal is a recipe for disaster, as this will make me VERY sick for the rest of the day. "Sick" = pain and seizures.) In short, every single part of the Ketogenic diet is the exact opposite of what my body needs to stay seizure-free. Now, I can never maintain a 100% seizure-free life, largely because there are other problems that can and do cause bouts of extreme pain and over which I have no control (most notably a certain "monthly" issue for us girls, which basically hasn't worked right in 20 years). Since pain is the currency upon which my seizures run, there are never any guarantees. Still, with a carefully balanced diet of vegetarian food (read: wheat gluten or "mock duck"), rice milk, going easy on "hard" vegetables (that cause me to have lengthy bouts of diarrhea), and significant spurts of sugar before every meal, I do fairly well. I don't lose much weight, but I'm not bedridden either. (I tend to only lose much weight when I am bedridden for at least 2 months on end, usually because my body stops accepting solid food at all - and no, I can't drink most "meal replacement" shakes because their fiber content exceeds the restricted amount I'm allowed, no more than 5g per meal or a total of 10g a day, i.e. 1/3rd of the normal recommended daily allowance.) Yeah, being me is... fun? -.-;


TL;DR - If you do have signifcant health concerns, don't wait for a doctor or anyone else to tell you what's right for your body. You'll have to figure it out for yourself. Whatever works for you and makes you feel better is what you should eat. (And really, people, we should stop trying to tell others what will "cure" them. Chances are, your special diet, essential oils, or whatever won't cure a long-term health issue, and you're probably not qualified to give advice on such things, anyway. The doctors are barely qualified to give advice that even approaches intelligent...)

I mean, the carb-insulin whatever model might theoretically be wrong (I can't confirm, I'm not a scientist), but in practice, it 100% works. Eating just carbs and protein doesn't cause you to gain too much weight. Eating just fat and protein also doesn't cause you to gain much weight. But eating fat and carbs together definitely causes you to gain more weight, especially if you eat a bit more fat and carbs together (think french fries soaked in oil for example). Even if you don't go on a keto diet and you just eat carb and fats in different meals, you still notice a huge weight loss benefit (for example eating your carbs plus some protein and a tiny touch of fat for lunch and protein plus fat in the evening). Again, this might be more complex than just the carb-insulin model, but it works in practice, so who cares.

Losing weight requires calorie deficit. The insulin response to carbs will make your body preserve fat stores in calorie deficit (you lose muscle mass and feel tired / hungry). Once transitioned to stable ketosis, being in calorie deficit will not make you tired or hungry and your body will burn fat stores.

The problem with most studies is that they do not account for the time necessary to transition into ketosis and do not use a low enough carb threshold to ensure that all participants stay in ketosis.

Also, people / studies generally consider long cardio sessions to be proper exercise, which they are not for weight loss. If you are trying to lose fat, no exercise would be better than cardio. You are not burning fat and you are making your body hungry for carbs through cardio. Stick to weight lifting and short HIIT workouts.

Point is, these studies pretend they are controlling for one variable when it is impossible to do so. All they are proving is that making a single factor lifestyle change does not lead to better health for most people (as if we didn't already know that).

Every time I see someone claim that low carb diets are "debunked," or "bro science," with any science to back up their claim, its the same data referring to a "low carb" diet that is 20% or more carbohydrate, i.e. not a well formulated keto diet. Ketosis happens when the body is in a specific hormonal profile that is very low in insulin and relatively high in Glucagon, for a long enough period of time to deplete the liver's stores of glycogen. If you're getting 20% of your calories from carbohydrate you can't reasonably expect your glycogen stores to get used up, and you will stay in a glucose-adapted state and continue storing fat rather than burning it.

I have experimented with a ketogenic diet, and it is absolutely amazing for both weight loss and aerobic performance. One fact that was not mentioned in this video is that you don't need the same amount of oxygen to do an equivalent amount of work. Ketosis is also a good state to be in if you plan on fasting.

Not mentioned is that getting off carbs stops food cravings which leads to naturally eating less; getting down to one meal a day is easy. Once you reach that point, multi-day fasts are then easy.

Calories, like weight, are poor gauges for weight loss.

As someone who has been studying lower carb and ketogenic nutrition for my personal edification for the last 20ish years I believe that saying a keto diet is high fat and low carb isn't perfectly accurate. Keto is definitely low carb, protein amount is based on your lean body mass, but the amount of fat you consume is dependent on how much of a calorie deficit you want to be in for weight loss, if you want to lose weight at all. Keto isn't just for weight loss so you can remain on a keto "diet" (eating style) once you hit maintenance, you just have to up your calorie intake in the form of fat. Since fat is so calorically dense it's easy to do. Also, I believe that keto is better for losing weight because insulin is a hunger hormone, and consuming carbs makes you produce more insulin than if you consume protein and fat. Eat carbs, insulin spikes and you get hungry faster. Eat protein and fat, insulin doesn't spike, and you are able to control both your appetite and your emotional desire for food better.

Because of the lack of controlled, long-term studies of different diets, how about we look at groups of people who have to eat different diets and try to see if they live longer or shorter. Which group of people who because of the terrain, economics, and climate has to eat a diet high in meat and low in everything else?


Mongolians and Inuit people. BTW, the keto diet people aren't eating anything close to what these people eat. The Inuit eat very fresh/raw meat and organs (like the liver), which actually contains a lot of glycogen (stored glucose). Mongolians eat cheese, milk, and yogurt, which contains sugar, too. They all eat the organs, while most "keto" dieters eat muscular meat, which usually has been aged for a few days depleting the stores of glycogen.


Are Inuits and Mongolians live all that long? No. Modern Mongolians die quite often from stroke and heart disease. Inuits have just about the same rate of heart attacks and twice as much stroke as North Americans. Life expectancy of Inuits lag behind that of other Canadians (with their fries dipped in gravy called poutine).


Which other groups seems to live longer? Mediterranean, Japanese, French. Their diets are varied: meat, fish, fermented milk (Mediterranean and French), fermented soy (Japanese), vegetables (both fresh and fermented), fruit (fresh and fermented, aka wine), and guess what, carbohydrates (wheat, rice, barley, etc ...) It appears that eating basically everything in moderation and not worrying too much about it make you live longer or something.

As a current nutrition student (finishing my BScN and following with MScN) the best thing stated in this episode is, “there’s no one size fits all diet.” I constantly hear people giving others advice on diets they’ve done. Saying, “this worked great for me. You should do it.” These statements coming from one person with no background in health/nutrition to their friends/family/coworkers etc.. Keto can help with epilepsy and as these studies mentioned here (albeit all of them have small sample size) suggest other cognitive conditions. While some can and do lose weight doing a keto program, they are risking long term complications. Under long term keto diets, the body can become less insulin sensitive, so when you go off keto, you have a harder time utilizing carbs. It also can impact your microbiome in the gut. They need fiber from veggies and fruit and the keto diet restricts these so much, one can permanently disrupt their healthy gut biome. It’s not to say that keto is bad, it’s just not the miracle diet that some proponents would have you believe. It’s good for some with certain needs, but it shouldn’t be the first thing one does to lose weight.

The only really difficult things to replace on the diet are potassium and fibre. Bananas are great for this, but they're hard to fit in most people's macros for the day because they're a bit sugary. Worst case scenario you can buy supplements. If you don't replenish potassium you'll get leg cramps, which are super painful.

For fibre, the absolute best way I've found is flax seeds. Fibre is technically a carbohydrate, but it doesn't "count" towards your daily intake of carbs for the day. Keto doesn't make you lose fat weight by itself.  BUT, the resulting shift in your metabolism to use/burn more fat allows you to skip meals (aka intermittent fasting) much more easily, and effectively use your stored body fat, which does lead to fat weight loss.   One can do unhealthy keto (e.g. not enough nutrient dense vegetables) and experience bad side effects, and/or simply intake as many calories as you did before starting the diet, and you wouldn't expect fat weight loss in that case.
